column3: The effect of tailored information, goal setting, and tailored feedback on household energy use, energy-related behaviors, and behavioral antecedents
column7: three-pronged intervention & three-pronged intervention + a "group goal of 5%" (reductions?) "as well as group feedback about average and total energy savings of all participants"
column8: three-part intervention of "tailored information about possibilities to reduce energy use, goal setting, and tailored feedback about energy savings" intended to produce "changes in direct and indirect energy use, changes in energy-related beha- viors, and changes in knowledge of energy conservation." Also some people "received a group goal of 5% as well as group feedback about average and total energy savings of all participants."
column39: this study is not aimed at reducing meat consumption, but reducing meat consumption is suggested as one of the strategies that people can pursue to reduce energy consumption. The Ns are a little conflusing because the paper varies between households (asdsigned)) and people actuallly doing the thing (in table 3 where outcomes are recorded). The paper also says that he average household is 2.5 people so the n_total numbers are from that. Last, there is a tricky problem here in capturing precvision with two interventions and one control group, and only one effet size presetnted for both groups. The way to count the number of interventions in the dataset accurately is to report two effect sizes (both the same thing because then at least the average is correct and we have no basis for marking them otherwise because of the combined effect size). However this has the effect of making effectively doubling the size of the control group. Does robumeta deal with this?

column3: “Meat” Me in the Middle: The Potential of a Social Norm Feedback Intervention in the Context of Meat Consumption – A Conceptual Replication
column8: message showing them “The results of last week show that the average meat consumption of Dutch residents was: 1.32 times per day.” In addition, participants in the descriptive norm only conditions received descriptive norm feedback: “Based on your answers, it appears that your meat consumption is above-/below- average compared to the average Dutch resident.” (but we didn't incldue that condition because the treatment is modified based on post-treatment data)
column10: self-reported MAP consumption: "During the three weeks of data collection, participants were asked to report their meat consumption on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays."
column39: Interesting study. but there's a second treatment condition I didn't include because of post-treatment non-randomness. Some people in the injunctive norm get a frowny face if they are eating above average meat and a smiley face if they are doing better than average. But that's based on baseline covariate data gathered in the data collection process, so effectively there are *two* treatments, one with a positive mersage and one with a negative, but the negative or positive message isn't randomly assigned. Final note: the overall effect size for that condition was 0.01.

column3: Shifting norms, static behaviour: effects of dynamic norms on meat consumption
column8: combination of a dynamic norm appeal (“More and more people in the UK are changing. In 2020, 33% of British people—a figure increasing every year over the previous 5 years—successfully engaged in one or more of the following behaviours to eat less meat" (and then some behaviors) and a graph showing that number going up over time
column10: the Food Frequency Questionnaire (FFQ), a structured recall task
column39: counting as a 2023 study because its preprint was available (10.31234/osf.io/tac3j). total null results and the authors report it that way: "Analyses for changes in self-reported meat consumption did not reach our evidential threshold." note that the Ns are taken from a footnote to table 6: "Excluding participants who were outliers on the FFQ. ns = 245, 243 251, 248, 238, respectively". I would not have advised excluding these people but maybe their answers were truly impossible. Aso noting that the SD is taken from Table 3, but otherwise we could have done 0.25 * sqrt(238) (the SE in table 6 * SD(n_c) and the two numbers are in the same ballpark

column3: Manipulating the symbolic meaning of meat to encourage greater acceptance of fruits and vegetables and less proclivity for red and white meat
column8: Being told of a scientific study that people who endorse social hierarchy and who embrace human dominance over nature are more likely to eat meat
column39: finds that people who reject hierarchy and dominance in the treatment group reduce their meat consumption but red and white meat consumption between the groups overall "remained constant" despite a rise in the fruits and veggies consumption rising in the treatment group. This is what the authors report. However table 4 tells us that actually the treatment group saw a meaningful reduction in red meat but not in white meat, with Ns they don't report elsewhere. (Perhaps different numbers of respondents answered different numbers of questions?) On the other hand, table 3 reports a tiny reduction in average servings per week that doesn't correspond to that result at all. The data analysis in this paper is a mess and the outcome is very crude. We could theoretically take table 4 as the canonical result but I think it makes more sense to just call this an unspecified null. If the authors had provided a SD of meat consumption in table 3 we'd be somewhere but lacking that I think we should take the authors at face value when they say that there was no effect. Also, 110 participants returned the follow-up surveys (p. 121), so the Ns should probably equal that, but their are different Ns reported all throughout the paper. So I just went with 55 and 55. That's approximately correct I suppose

column3: Nudge the Lunch: A Field Experiment Testing Menu-Primacy Effects on Lunch Choices
column7: placing meat or vegetarian item at the top of a menu
column8: in a university cafeteria with a big board displaying the day's options, either the vegetarian or the meat option was put at the top of the menu, with the fish item in the middle on days when it was available
column10: percentage vegetarian meals sold on average
column39: I like this stucdy for many reasons. First, it looks like a big result *but only if you ignore fish.* What's actually happening is that meat declines by 4 percentage points on control days, but only 1 percent of that is substitution towards vegetarian meals; the remaining 3 percentage points of that is towards fish, which is MAP. That's not nothing, but it's against a baseline percentage of So the effect size is 0.01, which, again is not *nothing* but it's also not going to be significant. Second, what I'm calling regression to the meat" they call "behavioral spillovers" and they addres it directly: "Behavioral spillovers can be both positive (adding to the effect) and negative (offsetting the effect). Thus, the claimed, although not perfectly evident, effect of the nudge, that individuals on average choose a more sustainable option for lunch and thereby reduce the effect on the climate, might be offset by behavioral spillover effects being present. Unfortunately, we cannot address these important questions with the data available in this study. This calls for further research." Third,  "Unfortunately, the data does not allow us to track the purchases of one person across days." Fourth, nice evidence of how it's just really hard to run these kinds of experiments: "The meat option was always displayed at the top of the menu on the website for the first part of the period, both for the daily and weekly menus. It was noted as the experiment went on that as from 1 April, six weeks into the schedule of randomization, the vegetarian option was placed at the top of the menu online." Fifth, in terms of total_ns, I am multiplying the average number of meals sold * the number of days, which is a simplifying assumption (that no one shows up more than once). I'm confident some people did however. This is a hard one .

column3: Nutritional changes among premenopausal women undertaking a soya based dietary intervention study in Hawaii
column5: Journal of Human Nutrition and Dietetics
column8: regular supplies of soya along with specific suggestions on how to incorporate soya foods into the daily menu, such as replacing meat with tofu in stew or fried dishes, cow milk with soyamilk, and cookies with a soya protein bar
column39: nice study, might exclude on account of deliberately feeding the people the soy and the ambiguity of the desired outcome but the procedure specifically says they were encouraged to substitute out meat.

column3: Risks of meat: the relative impact of cognitive, affective and moral concerns
column8: psychology students were presented with an article about risks of meat consumption and told that it was a summary of an extensive article published in a well-known Dutch newspaper. The article in the cognitive condition described risks of meat consumption in more cognitive terms
column10: index of meat consumption, ranging from 0 to about 700 grams per day
column39: no SD given but we're told there was overall no effect. at posttest the affective focus group eats more meat than the control group and the cognitive group eats less. if we had SD information this would be recorded as a minor backlash

column3: Risks of meat: the relative impact of cognitive, affective and moral concerns
column8: psychology students were presented with an article about risks of meat consumption and told that it was a summary of an extensive article published in a well-known Dutch newspaper. The article in the moral condition described these risks in moral terms
column10: index of meat consumption, ranging from 0 to about 700 grams per day
column39: no SD given but we're told there was overall no effect. We could maybe figure it out from some of the F tests but it seems that the most relevant F test (p. 203) is a combination of intentions and behavior so I wouldn't count that. It's also interesting that they suggest this great DV (grams of meat per day on a scale of 0 to 300) and then present outcomes in a totally different scale in the resutls section

column3: Investigating the Effectiveness of Message Framing and Regulatory Fit in Increasing Positive Animal Attitude and Reducing Animal Products Consumption. A study for Animal Equality
column8: facebook ad for people looking to help Animal Equality improve its research leading to six facebook posts about "sows; mothers in loneliness and despair", "An investigation reveals the suffering of tuna",  "Do you know how pigs live in factory farms?", "the truth behind the egg industry: baby chicks ground up alive", "inside slaughterhouses",  and " one minute video revealing the process through which in the dairy industry newborn calves are systematically taken away from their mothers, along with [PROMOTION MESSAGE ] that places emphasis to expectations, accomplishments, and development needs; it depicts goals as ideals, and carries a strategic concern with approaching gains (presence of positives) and avoiding non-gains (absence of positives).
column10: ordinal outcome for number of meals with MAP per week (0 times APC per week = 1, 1- 5 times APC per week = 2, 6-10 times APC per week = 3, 11-15 times APC per week = 4, 16-20 times APC per week = 5)
column39: interesting it was a top 3 charity by ACE's lights in 2015. i am a bit worried about the "manipulation check" which basically asks if people are open to the intended attitude change but it doesn't get mentioned much -- did they excllude based on it? -- so I'll not worry about it it. I also think the author slightly misinterprets the results in calling both moral shock conditions effective and the individualization messages ineffective, but that's what the paper says and that's what we shall report

column3: Investigating the Effectiveness of Message Framing and Regulatory Fit in Increasing Positive Animal Attitude and Reducing Animal Products Consumption. A study for Animal Equality
column8: facebook ad for people looking to help Animal Equality improve its research leading to six facebook posts about "sows; mothers in loneliness and despair", "An investigation reveals the suffering of tuna",  "Do you know how pigs live in factory farms?", "the truth behind the egg industry: baby chicks ground up alive", "inside slaughterhouses",  and " one minute video revealing the process through which in the dairy industry newborn calves are systematically taken away from their mothers, along with prevention message telling them that they can save lives just by changing their diets. This was intended to highlight themes of "security, responsibility, and safety necessities, frames goals as obligations, and carries a strategic concern with approaching non-losses (absence of negatives) and avoiding losses (presence of negatives)."

I believe our paper will be the first to cite it, ever. Again, not happy to be backing out the SD from confidence intervals but it is what we have

column3: Effects of a documentary on consumer perception of the environmental impact of meat consumption
column8: students watched Cowspiracy or an environmental video in a group setting
column10: days per week of having meat
column38: adults (18+) with an average age in their late 20s (the control group was about 4 years older on average)
column39: nice study, unfortunately there's such large dropoff by the year follow-up that we're below the 25 participant threshold in intervention 1 and control. Also the people who still report a year later ate much less meat in general (figure 3) which is interesting and a bit unexpected. "The results for the self- reported meat consumption frequency pointed in the same direction but without being significant." Yes but i wonder if they would have been if they had done a DiD between groups comparison. Instead they check for whether the change was significant within each group, but "The Difference Between “Significant” and “Not Significant” is not Itself Statistically Significant"

column39: the implementation issues here are a cautionary tale about field experiments, but still it's good that they actually published the data! protocol registered here https://osf.io/3vrqj/. The Ns are a bit of guesswork, but Elif emailed to give average numbers of meals per intervention period, whcih I multipled by the number of restaurants times the number of days times a slight discount (0.9) to account for potential repeat customers

column3: Educational interventions and animal consumption: Results from lab and field studies
column8: Participants read a philosophical ethics paper by the ethicist Mylan Engel (2002) that discussed the ethics of consuming animals for food. The focus of the paper was to argue that most people are already morally committed not to eat animals.
column10: Twenty-four-hour food frequency questionnaire: "In the past day, how many times did you consume the following food and drinks?” Participants could respond from 0 times to 5 or more times for the following items: Dairy, chicken, turkey, fish, pork, eggs, beef, bacon, sausages, processed meats, hamburgers, or any animal meat (any kind)." Responses were coded from 0-5, and we used the sum of items in analyses."

column3: Educational interventions and animal consumption: Results from lab and field studies

The focus of the paper was to elucidate a basic argument concerning animals that causing unnecessary pain is wrong and animals in factory farms experience unnecessary pain.

Responses were coded from 0-5, and we used the sum of items in analyses."

column3: Educational interventions and animal consumption: Results from lab and field studies
column8: read an educational pamphlet about the conditions of factory farmed animals called “Compassionate Choices: If You Care about Animals, Please Consider not Eating Them.” The pamphlet was sixteen A5 sized pages discussing various aspects of factory farming, including the effects on the animals and human health. The pamphlet also included tips for reducing animal consumption including alternatives to animal products.
column10: Twenty-four-hour food frequency questionnaire: "In the past day, how many times did you consume the following food and drinks?” Participants could respond from 0 times to 5 or more times for the following items: Dairy, chicken, turkey, fish, pork, eggs, beef, bacon, sausages, processed meats, hamburgers, or any animal meat (any kind). Responses were coded from 0-5, and we used the sum of items in analyses."

column3: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings
column8: survey with embedded statement: "“Did you know? On average, 44% of our canteen customers chose a vegan or vegetarian main dish during the last winter term."
column39: I think the study takes place in Schleswig-Holstein based on the flyer they provide. The data for effect sizes comes form this paragraph on p. 7: "The share of selected vegan/vegetarian dishes was 62% in both control groups. For the meat descriptive norm and the vegetarian descriptive norm, we find a share of 57% vegan/vegetarian meal choices. Of the participants that received the meat guessed norm, 60% chose a vegan/vegetarian meal, while 64% in the vegetarian guessed norm group chose a vegan/vegetarian meal."

column3: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings
column8: survey with embedded statement: "Did you know? On average, 56% of our canteen customers chose a main dish containing meat or fish during the last winter term."

column3: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings

column39: I am not thrilled to be backing out an SD from the SE but that's what we've got. Substantively the result is right; it should be about a null and it'll show up that way. I also wonder about excluding this study on the basis of its control group:, who received "the pamphlet The Cruelty Behind the Cuteness, a pamphlet produced by the Humane Society of the United States. It discusses problems with “puppy mills.” It does not mention diet."

column3: Effect of Multimedia Education on Nutritional Behaviour for Colorectal Cancer Prevention: An Application of Health Belief Model
column8: audiovisual CD with information about colorectal cancer, information about benefits of increasing the consumption of fruits and vegetables, the benefits of a high-fibre diet, and the benefits of restricting meat and high-fat foods; and suggestions on how to prepare a variety of healthy, non-meat and vegetable-based foods
column10: audiovisual CD that contained 45 min of materialabout colorectal cancer, the benefits of eating more vegetables and restricting meat, and educational videos on how to cook healthy vegetarian meals
column39: the effect size is a bit of guesswork here, as is the sign. apparently red meat reduced significantly in treatment vs control but what actually seems to have happened is that red meat stayed constant in treatment from 0 to 6 months and went up in control, but white meat went down in control by a lot but just by a little in treatment. so I'm just summing the numbers in table 4 and dividing by the pooled SD from table 3. Is this nul> I think so, if you average them together. IF you care about health this treatment 'worked' (maybe just prevented regression to the mean?) but really who can say and also the intervention is not described in much detail. I feel comfortable iwth this level of ambiguity, delta = 0.11 is probaboly about right for the overall changes

column3: Nudge interventions to reduce fish sauce consumption in Thailand
column8: Variations on how fish sauces is served and presented in Thai university cafeterias. In this condition, fish sauce was served in a bowl and pepole served themselves with a spoon rather than squeezing fish sauce from a bottle
column10: grams of fish sauce per day
column39: Noting four judgment calls. First, I take 'total grams of fish sauce sold per day' as the relevant outcome because that's closest to 'does this intervention reduce MAP consumption on net or not." The outcomes are all broadly similar in range, although the total consumption values are a bit smaller than the per-person numbers. That's completely fine, it's just that the study is aiming at reducing salt intake per person and what we're interested in is not quite that. Second, I excluded the condition with the information: " “Do not add more than 2/3 teaspoons of fish sauce per meal”. Maybe some people took this as mandatory -- I think I would have and thus we're not getting any effect of voluntary reduction but something closer to just taking fish sauce away. Third, Ns are a bit of guesswork, they tell us number of meals sold in each condition per canteen and then I multiply that by 0.9 to accomodate some amount of repeat visiting per canteen. There is probably crossover between conditions per week in any case. Fourth, I redid the significance calculations b/c of the difference in variable we vs. the study's authors are interested in.

The information sheet also showed a picture of a smartwatch with a healthy heart, a 120/80 blood pressure reading, a positive reinforcement message “GREAT JOB”, and a short message reading: “Less salty, reduces disease, weight, and bloating”."

column8: leaflets with vegan, vegetarian, less meat and combination messages respectively further subidivided into leaflets of different lengths
column39: The key takeaway from this study is that the control group declined significantly on self-reported meat consumption, so even most of the other groups declined a bit as well, the effects come out looking mostly null and a little bit backlash-y. I ended up redoing the stats from scratch based on the data and a conversation with Jacob. Basically I filtered out all groups where N < 25 and there's no data on the Total_Chg variable (which is the d_i_d var). Now arguably we could try to figure something out with just the endline data and get larger Ns but there's a tradeoff there for one kind of precision vs. another and it's a lot more straightforward to limit the analysis to folks who have Total_Chg scores reported

column39: the reporting for study 2 here is a bit of a mess. The Ns are a guess from the number of participants times attrition at time 3 and there are no listed effect sizes, so there's definitely a lot of guesswork here. Having said that, that's what the authros provide and it does provide pretty solid evidence against a lot of theories. I'd say "don't do online studies and hope to change real-life eating behavior" is one of our paper's big takeaways. Online studies are well-suited for online behaviors

column3: Developing a Scalable Dynamic Norm Menu-Based Intervention to Reduce Meat Consumption
column8: dynamic norm message added to the menu at a college campus sports café (presumably Jimmy's?) saying "Our Meatless Burgers Are on the Rise" and also the ordering tablet says "We’ve noticed customers are starting to choose more meatless dishes."
column10: a meal's having meat or not
column39: I like this study because of its very nice design but its statistical results are a bit hard to integrate into a meta-analysis. I'm not seeing much in the way of baseline or population standards for proportion of vegetarian meals on a control day. What we really want is proportion of vegetarian meals ordered on the treatment days minus proportion of vegetarian meals ordered on control days without covariates and we want both data points reported. Instead we have z scores which are beta / se and theoretically se = sd / sqrt(n) assuming no covariates (which there are) so hypothetically we can convert z to via z/sqrt(n). However before we publish for real let's see if we can get to the bottom of this.  I am also using Ns from the total number of pariticpants, subtracting the percentage that ordered multple meals or meals for others & dividing by two

column39: Studies 3 and 4 are the gold standard for field experiments in this literature, and if you average them together, it's a big fat null. I am taking the Ns from the "number of observations" in table 3 and assuming that the average might either show up more than once or order more than one thing. Again, total guesswork.
